answer_html: There is a free choice like before and we choose \(\displaystyle y_1 = 1\), then \(\displaystyle y_2 = -i\) and have the eigenvector \(\displaystyle y = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-i\end{pmatrix}\).
answer_latex:
There is a free choice like before and we choose
$\displaystyle y_1 = 1$, then $\displaystyle y_2 = -i$ and have the
eigenvector $\displaystyle y = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-i\end{pmatrix}$.
hints_html:
The eigenvectors are the non-trivial vectors that satisfy

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}(A-\lambda{}I)\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}.\end{aligned}\]

Setting the determinant to be zero (when finding the eigenvalues) is what makes such vectors possible.

Calculate vectors \(\displaystyle x\) and \(\displaystyle y\) which satisfy

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} -1-\lambda_1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 - \lambda_1\end{pmatrix}x = 0\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{pmatrix} -1-\lambda_2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 - \lambda_2\end{pmatrix}y = 0\end{aligned}\]

These correspond to the two eigenvalues from part (a).
hints_raw:
The eigenvectors are the non-trivial vectors that satisfy

:<math>
\displaystyle{}(A-\lambda{}I)\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{0}.
</math>

Setting the determinant to be zero (when finding the eigenvalues) is what makes such vectors possible.
Calculate vectors <math> \displaystyle x</math> and <math>\displaystyle y</math> which satisfy

:<math> \begin{pmatrix} -1-\lambda_1 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 - \lambda_1\end{pmatrix}x = 0 </math>
and
:<math> \begin{pmatrix} -1-\lambda_2 & -2 \\ 2 & -1 - \lambda_2\end{pmatrix}y = 0 </math>

These correspond to the two eigenvalues from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_8_(a)|part (a)]].
question: 8 (b)
sols_html:
We first calculate the eigenvector \(\displaystyle x\) of the eigenvalue \(\displaystyle -1 -2i\),

\(0 = \begin{pmatrix}-1-(-1-2i) & -2 \\ 2 & -1-(-1-2i)\end{pmatrix} x = \begin{pmatrix}2i & -2 \\ 2 & 2i\end{pmatrix} x = \begin{pmatrix}2i x_1 - 2x_2 \\ 2x_1 + 2ix_2\end{pmatrix} = 0\)

Considering the first line, we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2ix_1 - 2x_2 &= 0\\ x_2 &= ix_1\end{aligned}\]

Notice that there is a free variable which is common when finding eigenvectors. Therefore, we can choose \(\displaystyle x_1 = 1\), then \(\displaystyle x_2 = i\) and have the eigenvector \(\displaystyle x = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\i\end{pmatrix}\).

For the second eigenvector \(\displaystyle y\) of the eigenvalue \(\displaystyle -1+2i\), we calculate

\(0 = \begin{pmatrix}-2i & -2 \\ 2 & -2i\end{pmatrix} y = \begin{pmatrix}-2i y_1 - 2y_2 \\ 2y_1 - 2iy_2\end{pmatrix} = 0\)

Considering the first line, we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -2iy_1 - 2y_2 &= 0\\ y_2 &= -iy_1\end{aligned}\]

There is a free choice like before and we choose \(\displaystyle y_1 = 1\), then \(\displaystyle y_2 = -i\) and have the eigenvector \(\displaystyle y = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-i\end{pmatrix}\).
sols_latex:
We first calculate the eigenvector $\displaystyle x$ of the eigenvalue
$\displaystyle -1 -2i$,

$0 = \begin{pmatrix}-1-(-1-2i) & -2 \\ 2 & -1-(-1-2i)\end{pmatrix} x = \begin{pmatrix}2i & -2 \\ 2 & 2i\end{pmatrix} x 
 = \begin{pmatrix}2i x_1 - 2x_2 \\ 2x_1 + 2ix_2\end{pmatrix}  = 0$

Considering the first line, we obtain

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle 2ix_1 - 2x_2 &= 0\\
x_2 &= ix_1
\end{align*}

Notice that there is a free variable which is common when finding
eigenvectors. Therefore, we can choose $\displaystyle x_1 = 1$, then
$\displaystyle x_2 = i$ and have the eigenvector
$\displaystyle x = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\i\end{pmatrix}$.

For the second eigenvector $\displaystyle y$ of the eigenvalue
$\displaystyle -1+2i$, we calculate

$0 = \begin{pmatrix}-2i & -2 \\ 2 & -2i\end{pmatrix} y 
 = \begin{pmatrix}-2i y_1 - 2y_2 \\ 2y_1 - 2iy_2\end{pmatrix}  = 0$

Considering the first line, we obtain

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle -2iy_1 - 2y_2 &= 0\\
y_2 &= -iy_1
\end{align*}

There is a free choice like before and we choose
$\displaystyle y_1 = 1$, then $\displaystyle y_2 = -i$ and have the
eigenvector $\displaystyle y = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-i\end{pmatrix}$.

We first calculate the eigenvector <math> \displaystyle x</math>  of the eigenvalue <math>\displaystyle -1 -2i</math>,

<math> 0 = \begin{pmatrix}-1-(-1-2i) & -2 \\ 2 & -1-(-1-2i)\end{pmatrix} x = \begin{pmatrix}2i & -2 \\ 2 & 2i\end{pmatrix} x 
 = \begin{pmatrix}2i x_1 - 2x_2 \\ 2x_1 + 2ix_2\end{pmatrix}  = 0</math>

Considering the first line, we obtain

:<math>
\begin{align}
\displaystyle 2ix_1 - 2x_2 &= 0\\
x_2 &= ix_1
\end{align}
</math>

Notice that there is a free variable which is common when finding eigenvectors.  Therefore, we can choose <math>\displaystyle x_1 = 1</math>, then <math>\displaystyle x_2 = i</math> and have the eigenvector <math>\displaystyle x = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\i\end{pmatrix}</math>.


For the second eigenvector <math>\displaystyle y</math> of the eigenvalue <math> \displaystyle -1+2i</math>, we calculate

<math> 0 = \begin{pmatrix}-2i & -2 \\ 2 & -2i\end{pmatrix} y 
 = \begin{pmatrix}-2i y_1 - 2y_2 \\ 2y_1 - 2iy_2\end{pmatrix}  = 0</math>

Considering the first line, we obtain

:<math>
\begin{align}
\displaystyle -2iy_1 - 2y_2 &= 0\\
y_2 &= -iy_1
\end{align}
</math>

There is a free choice like before and we choose <math>\displaystyle y_1 = 1</math>, then <math>\displaystyle y_2 = -i</math> and have the eigenvector <math>\displaystyle y = \begin{pmatrix} 1\\-i\end{pmatrix}</math>.
statement_html:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -2\\ 2 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}\) is the vector of unknown functions.

Find the corresponding eigenvectors.
statement_raw:
Consider the 2 x 2 system of differential equations

:<math>
\mathbf{x}'(t)=\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  -2\\
2  &  -1
\end{bmatrix} \mathbf{x}(t)
</math>

where <math>\mathbf{x}(t)=\begin{bmatrix}x_1(t)\\x_2(t)\end{bmatrix}</math> is the vector of unknown functions.

Find the corresponding eigenvectors.
